Review Text: A large structure slightly neglected with elephant walls the Yatala Vehara a Buddhist stupa dating back to the 3rd Century B.C and seemingly ignored in a quiet spot in the town. No tourists, no entry fee. With another couple of large stupas in the town it is worth an hour or two in a tuk tuk visiting them.
We were surprised that it was so unkempt. It had a load of artifacts which were of archeological value. Visit the mesuem by the side of the pagoda.
Worth to visit, it's on your way to Kataragama. Recommended to visit there and to get a historical, religious  experiences.

Right by the roadside for a handy stop. One of the lesser visited stupas. The elephant frieze here is in brick. Over 2 millenniums old. Worth a brief look in passing. A little less well maintained than many other Temples.

We had a few hours to spare before our afternoon safari so we followed the main road to visit this site.  There is a small parking area in front. At first, we thought that the stupa was off limits to visitors because the small iron gate/fence was closed.  When we walked the small bridge over the lily pond to get closer to the eroded brick elephant wall, we noticed that the gate was unlocked so we stepped inside. The site could use a new coat of paint and maintenance.  It is easy to see that the statues and Buddhas were ancient but there was very little signage.  There were two small houses/structures to the left and right, outside the elephant wall but we did not know which was the museum so we did not wish to intrude. We saw several similar stupas that appeared much cleaner and nicer surrounded with colorful Buddhist flags.  This one stood out because it was surrounded by a small pond and eroded elephant wall.
Beautiful, quite temple by roadside . Lot of people visiting Kataragama miss this place with a history running beyond two millennia . There is a museum also.
Beautiful and serene construction. Requiring a bit of maintenance and a tidy up, but still worthwhile to pull-in at the side of the road for some time to view and take some photos.

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. We walked to this dagoba from our hotel en were charmed by the way it is surrounded by water with water lilies. The brick elephans were also beautiful, as were the ancient statues standing around the dagoba. In the dagoba there are some huge holes which showed the massiveness of the dagoba, but the reason for them we could not discover. At the right side is a small archeological museum, that may have given the answer, but our sons did not want to go to a museum...

Very quaint Stupa surrounded by a lovely lily pond. It is painted in the usual brilliant white and catches the sun beautifully. It is right beside the lake which makes for a lovely walk. We were in Tissa for two days doing Yala Safaris. If you are doing likewise this stupa makes for a nice visit.
If you are passing this temple en route to your destination, this is a good place to visit since a museum is also situated next to the temple, showcasing the history of Sir Lanka..
If you are staying in Tissa and have time to explore the town - e.g., before / after  a Safari, this is nice to visit and you can easily walk from the Tissa main road
This dagoba here is smaller than the main one to the east, but it's quaint in its own way, as it's surrounded by a moat with lotus leaves. It also offers more tranquility, as it's not as crowded.
Very peaceful, people seem to forget leave this pagoda out. There is a small museum to the side that has pieces dating back to 2BC.

The place is quiet big and very neatly maintained. I liked the Pure white color be it the temple exterior or the white clothes of the locals and even the hotel linen and bathrooms are sparkling white. Its really amazing

I live in Sri lanka and have never even heard of this temple let alone visited. This time traveling to kataragama did some research ad this temple was on my iteniary. I was very very impressed. Dating more than 2500 years. Supposed to have been built by king mahanaaga to give thanks for the birth of his son yatala tissa ad also for escaping an assassination attempt. These is a small museum which is full of ancient artifacts including the face of lord buddha made of moonstones and an ancient toilet used by the priests. The staff of the museum very knowledgeable ad went out of their way to explain the history of the temple ad the artifacts. The temple itself is surrounded by a moat.. Beautiful ad peaceful environment.

Fascinating place right next to the main road from Debarawewa to Tissa. Huge dagoba apparently filled with earth with some interesting carvings on the perimeter walls. Nice setting with water around. Ancient and interesting.

This place is a 'must' for anyone travelling in the Tissamaharama area and interested in the history of Buddhism. It is a huge stupa believed to have been built some 2,300 years ago. It is surrounded by a fascinating wall with sculpures of details of elephant heads and you can also see a traditional moonstone. The whole place is tranquil and exudes a sense of calm.
We accidentally took de tour and came across this dageba. It was really a beautiful area. not a popular place, but a must visit.
Very interesting museum with a very knowledgeable curator who spoke English and could tell about the various artifacts stored there.
This is a historical Wehera and need to be taken care by the authorities. Visited in the night and there were not enough lights to lit up.

Yatala Dagoba It is the same with this Dagoba, I saw this Dagoba and I had to see it. I walked from town 20 minutes to check it out. It was listed in my guide book & I LOVE Buddhist temples for their serenity so I must go, eh?

good regigious place with nice history. Ruins very well visible and nice renovation of the main stupa in its classic form. strange to see this building surrounded by a beautiful pond with its stunning flowers.
The most striking thing about this pagoda it its surrounded by a moat most probably for protection. And this is a very calm temple. Also don't forget to visit the small museum there.

This Tempel is incredible, very old and just so beautiful. I totally fell in love with this over 2000 year old structure. There are very interesting statutes all around the temple and it has elephant faces all around the outside wall along the pond. Also do go and see the museum where you will see incredible very old Buddha statutes and Buddha head made of moonstone. Must not be missed
Good Place to visit with a lake nearby. It is a holy religious place and should be respected. A bird sanctuary is close to this place.

The ancient dagoba of Yatala Wehera is situated on the main road to Tissa. The dagoba itself has mainly historical value (said to be over 2000 years old) but is nicely situated among lotus ponds. Just outside the dagoba is a small museum building, which has ancient statues (including a Buddha head made of moonstone) and an ancient bidet. When we arrived the museum was not open, but the caretakers rushed of on bike to get the key - and gave us an insightful tour.
This Pagoda is the oldest in this area of Tissa. Just along the roadside so very easy to access. Surrounding Lotus pond adds a senic beauty to the location.

This is a really old pagoda which has a moat around it. There are stalks and birds in the water and it's quite beautiful if it wasn't for all the rubbish floating in the water and on the land. It's definately worth a stop if you're en route but personally I would do a special trip for it just yet.
Historical temple....by the main road.......quick stop......go to Yala or Kataragama......not crowded......talk to the priests.......ask the history of the temple! Take a photo with them!
